ranked_diseases.explanation: Male patient with progressive proximal > distal weakness, Gowers sign, calf pseudohypertrophy, highly elevated CK, and typical age of onset. Classic presentation of DMD.
Milder allelic variant of dystrophinopathy. Similar features to DMD but typically later onset and slower progression. Age 9 with significant symptoms makes DMD more likely.
Gamma-sarcoglycanopathy can present similarly to DMD with proximal weakness, high CK, and calf hypertrophy, but less common than dystrophinopathies.
Alpha-sarcoglycanopathy with severe childhood onset can mimic DMD. High CK and proximal weakness pattern fit, but calf pseudohypertrophy less common.
Beta-sarcoglycanopathy with DMD-like presentation. Compatible features but less likely given typical DMD phenotype in male patient.
FKRP-related dystrophy can have childhood onset with high CK and proximal weakness, but calf hypertrophy and Gowers sign less typical.
X-linked form with contractures and weakness, but typically has early contractures, cardiac involvement, and lower CK elevation than observed.
Calpainopathy can have childhood onset with high CK, but contractures typically occur later and calf hypertrophy is uncommon.
